lines.text: am I the only one who can see it? And if so, what must I look like to them?
A wink from a pretty girl at a party results rarely in climax, Karl. But a man is a fool not to push a suggestion as far as it will go.
So you see... Radl. Under the terms of that document, even I find myself under your personal command!
Sturmbannfuhrer Stauff was doing his duty!

He reminds me of something that I occasionally pick up on my shoe in the gutter! Very unpleasant, on a hot day. And if you have the dubious honor of commanding this senseless slaughter, then I'd advise you to keep him downwind at all times! That is, of course, if you can tell the difference anymore.
Colonel, there's no such thing as "death with honor". Just death.
I have no intention of dying now. But if I'm going to, allow me to choose where and how.
[last lines]

[Molly reading letter from Liam. The letter is read in Liam's voice]
Molly, my love... as a great man once said, I have suffered to see change and yet nothing can ever be the same again. I came here to Norfolk to do a job... not to fall in love. By now you'll know the worst of me. Try not to think it. To leave you... is punishment enough. But it will not end here. For as they say in Ireland, we have known the days. Liam.

[reading mission orders from Hitler]
"Herr Oberst Radl is acting under my direct and personal orders in a matter of the utmost importance to the Reich. All personnel, military and civil, without distinction of rank, will assist him in any way that Oberst Radl sees fit to demand... Adolf Hitler."

[Handing Devlin an envelope]
Your complete instructions
What - all of it?
[Holds the envelope to his ear and crinkles it]
No cyanide pill?
I couldn't conceive of a situation which would require you to take one!
If anything happens to Churchill, they're going to hang you from Big Ben by your balls.
Your meeting went well? The Führer had something specific in mind?
he merely wants Winston Churchill brought from London to Berlin. And we are ordered to make a feasibility study. Today's Wednesday. By Friday he will forget it, but Himmler will not.
[Seen fighting in a churchyard, speaks as he fights]

It's all right, Father, I'm just telling him about the Holy Trinity. You know it? Footwork, timing, and hitting! And a little bit of dirty work. Learn these, my uncle'd say, and you'll inherit the Earth as surely as the meek.
Where you from, son?
Omaha, sir.
By this time next year pigeons are going to be crapping on statues of you across the whole damn state of Nebraska.
[Devlin has just provided Steiner with a much-needed resource]
Mr. Devlin, you are an extraordinary man.
Col. Steiner, you're an extraordinary judge of character.
You are going to jump in those clothes?

It might look a bit silly going down Mr. Steiner, but i'll be hell of a lot safer when i land on the ground. There is an old poem i know, which freely translated from the Irish says; i realized fear one morning, when the blare of the fox-hunters sound. When they are all chasing after the poor bloody fox, it's safer to be dressed like a hound.
You're quite a literary man, Devlin.
The truth be known, Colonel, I'm a bloody literary genius.
Herr Oberst Radl? In the name of the Fuhrer, you are under arrest.
May I be permitted to know the charge?

[a Nazi paratrooper has died while rescuing a drowning girl, revealing the plot to kidnap Churchill]
Colonel, I understand none of this. And I don't wish you well. But i'm grateful for the life of my child.
So am I.
Colonel, my one consolation is that that thanks to my sister, your plot has failed.
Really? I thought the plot failed because one of my men died saving the little girl out there.

[about SS-Obergruppenfuhrer]
There you are. You see Hans? It's infallible. I can always tell a thorough-going bastard when I see one.
You think I'd sell out.
It's just that you've been so expensive to buy in the first place.

I'm sure you could find a hundred things wrong with me, Mr. Devlin. A thousand. But you wouldn't throw me out of your bed on a wet saturday night i'm sure. That's men for you! Anything is better than nothing.
Wait a minute, come here!

You don't know the first thing about me. Because if you did you'd know that i much prefer a warm afternoon under the pines to a wet Saturday night any day. And the sand has a terrible way of getting where it shouldn't be.
[first lines]

[WWII News Story]
September 12, 1943, German paratroopers snatched Mussolini from his mountaintop prison in Italy.

That is one George Fowler lying there. He is a variety artist, of a sort. And a very brave man. Incredible! He knew this sort of thing could happen; he didn't even call out. Played it straight through to the end.
This operation could make the Charge of the Light Brigade look like a sensible military exercise!
Give me another one of those Bolshevik firecrackers. I think I fell asleep in the snow!
My God, You're a German!
More bloody foreigners!
[seeing the german paratroopers in the air]
Mother of God... Flying pigs!
Hello Grandfather!
Foreigners?
Polish. Corpral Kuniski.
Kuniski? Well, that's not your fault, son, is it?

[to the pilot]
How do I jump out of this thing?
Undo your safety belt. I turn the aircraft upside down, you drop out.

[turning to Steiner]
Has it occurred to you that piece of paper you keep waving about could just be a clever forgery?
Why don't you fly to Berchestgarden and ask him yourself?
Oh, let's not bother the man!
[the disguised Steiner gets into the jeep with Capt. von Neustadt]

[under his breath]
Not too slowly...
And on the *left... hand... side* of the road!
The only time this plan makes any sense to me is when I'm drunk.
You speak English?
Yes.
I'm gonna give you five minutes to lay down your arms, and surrender your hostages. You understand what I'm saying?
Yes.
Where's your commanding officer?
Yes.
Are you makin' fun of me, soldier?
[Kuniski just grins]

[after using a whistle to subdue a gauard dog at the airfield]
A little trick I learnt from an uncle I've got in Belfast.
In the Middle Ages, they'd have burned you for that!
